item.title: Turbopilot
item.description: Photo by Mitchell Luo on Unsplash Project Summary The TurboPilot project was an experimental runtime for getting open source, generative large-language-models to do code-completion on commodity computers without racks full of power-hungry GPUs. It was a learning opportunity for me to familiarise myself with Georgi Gerganov’s state-of-the-art llama.cpp quantized model runtime and served as an early proof-of-concept that local code completion is possible. This project received a large amount of attention on twitter, reddit and hackernews and gained almost 4k stars on github.

item.title: SAPIENTA
item.description: Photo by Russ Ward on Unsplash Project Summary The SAPIENTA Project originally led by Prof Maria Liakata was first presented in a journal paper in 2012. The system provides automatic annotation of Core Scientific Concepts in papers at sentence level. In 2013, I took over maintaining SAPIENTA. I was employed by Prof. Liakata through the University of Warwick to rewrite the core system in Python (the original was PERL-based) and I also added some enhancements including an improved web service, automatic PDF to XML conversion and a web UI.

item.title: CD^2CR
item.description: Photo by Volodymyr Hryshchenko on Unsplash Project Summary As part of my PHD work I spent some time looking at ways to automatically link between news articles and scientific papers that they mention. One of the difficulties can be that language use changes significantly between the two document types. A news article might say Fossil found of dinosaur killed in asteroid strike and the scientific paper might say The Chicxulub impact played a crucial role in the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction.

item.title: indiescrobble.club
item.description: Photo by Alex Litvin on Unsplash Project Summary Since December 2021 I’ve been very interested in the Indieweb movement and technologies. I watch a lot of TV and movies and listen to a lot of music and I wanted a way to be able to keep a diary of these things through my blog. So I built IndieScrobble - a system that allows you to log what you watched/listened to, how you rated it and give a little commentary and post this back to your website via micropub.

item.title: HarriGT
item.description: Photo by AbsolutVision on Unsplash Project Summary I’ve spent a lot of time trying to understand links between news articles and scientific papers as part of my PhD work. I built HarriGT as a way to semi-automatically find news articles that discuss scientific papers. The tool uses named entity recognition to identify potential names of academics and universities and then searches the Microsoft Academic Knowledge Graph, Springer API and CrossRef for publications that might match.

item.title: Partridge
item.description: Photo by IÃ±aki del Olmo on Unsplash Project Summary Partridge was my first foray into text processing pipelines, starting as a final year undergraduate project back in 2012. The idea was to index scientific papers and make them easily to search by annotating each sentence with tags showing which core scientific concept1 the sentence corresponds to. This makes it easy to carry out very targetted and specific literature searches. For example “Find biology papers where CRISPR is mentioned in a ‘Method’ sentence”.

item.title: Projects and Software
item.description: I’ve worked on quite a few open and closed source projects - feel free to take a look at my github profile. Below are a selection of open source projects that I am most proud of or have been the primary contributer on. I don’t have as much time as I’d like to maintain these projects but I do when I get chance. Feel free to contact me on twitter if you’re interested in helping out with any of the below projects.

item.title: ML Resources
item.description: Here are a selection of machine learning, AI and NLP resources you may find helpful. Getting Started with AI and ML I wrote some articles about the machine learning development cycle and how you should train and test models back when I worked at IBM. Cognitive Quality Assurance - An Introduction Cognitive Quality Assurance pt. 2 - Performance Metrics Essays and FAQs An assortment of essays and articles on philosophical concepts and frequently-asked-questions around AI concepts:
